titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the David P. Gamble papers LSC.1997
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Jesse D. Ruskin in 2013 in the Center for Primary Research and Training (CFPRT), with assistance from Jillian Cuellar; machine-readable finding aid created by Caroline Cub√©.

p.date: Online finding aid last updated 2021 September 1.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-09-01 15:33:09 -0700.

physdesc.extent: (54 record cartons, 32 document boxes, 3 flat boxes)

did.abstract: Anthropologist David P. Gamble was born in 1920 in Northern Ireland and passed away in California in 2011 after a long career of research and teaching. The collection contains a variety of material related to Gamble's more than six decades of work on The Gambia and its peoples. Copies of the anthropologist's publications on Gambian history, economics, languages, and cultures are included, along with many of the notes, maps, illustrations, primary sources, and secondary sources from which he generated these studies. Gamble's output was wide-ranging, but of special note are his contributions to the bibliography of The Gambia; the ethno-linguistic study of Wolof, Mandinka, and Fula; and the early history of the Gambia River region.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.
did.langmaterial: Materials are primarily in English and French; some materials in Wolof, Mandinka, Fula, and Jola.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Copyright to portions of this collection has been assigned to the UCLA Library Special Collections. The library can grant permission to publish for materials to which it holds the copyright. All requests for permission to publish must be submitted in writing to Library Special Collections. Credit shall be given as follows: The Regents of the University of California on behalf of the UCLA Library Special Collections.

acqinfo.head: Provenance/Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Collection acquired from David P. Gamble and Linda K. Salmon between 2011 and 2012.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], David P. Gamble Papers (Collection 1997). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Jesse D. Ruskin in 2013 in the Center for Primary Research and Training (CFPRT), with assistance from Jillian Cuellar. Collection has been partially processed. Series 1 to 6 have been processed to the file level, with books and photo clippings processed to the box level. Series 7 to 12 have not been processed, but general content of each box has been indicated.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biography/History
bioghist.p: David P. Gamble was born in 1920 in Northern Ireland and passed away in California in 2011 after a long career of anthropological research and teaching. Completing his undergraduate studies at University College, London in 1941, Gamble spent several years assisting with archaeological and physical studies of highland communities in Northern Ireland. After a brief stint in the Royal Engineers, he joined the Colonial Administrative Service in 1944 in the Gold Coast (now Ghana), taking up posts in Tarkwa, Axim, and Sekondi. At that time, Gamble's academic supervisor Daryll Forde, who was then Director of the International African Institute, began conceiving a series of studies, later known as the Ethnographic Survey of Africa, which aimed to fill wide gaps in ethnographic knowledge of the continent. The Gambia was viewed as a site in need of research. Gamble's other mentor, economic anthropologist Raymond Firth, also conducted a survey of what was then British West Africa and came to the same conclusion. At Forde's and Firth's urging, Gamble conducted field research among Mandinka, Wolof, Jola, and Fula communities in The Gambia between 1946 and 1958, initially with the support of a Colonial Research Fellowship and later as a Research Officer under The Gambia Government. With a dissertation on the socioeconomic conditions of the Mandinka village Kerewan, Gamble earned his Ph.D. in anthropology from the University of London in 1958. The anthropologist returned to The Gambia for research numerous times between 1963 and 1986. Published in 1967, Gamble's The Wolof of Senegambia, Together with Notes on the Lebu and the Serer became a valuable addition to Forde's Ethnographic Survey. Among many other publications, Gamble produced a 52-volume series of studies on Gambian history, society, and culture, titled Gambian Studies (1977-2007). In 1999, as a culmination of his work on early Gambian history, Gamble edited a scholarly edition of The Discovery of River Gambra (1623) by Richard Jobson.

Gamble began his academic career with teaching and research appointments at the University of Edinburgh (1959-1963), San Francisco State College (1963-1965), Queen's University Belfast (1965-1966), and Njala University College in Sierra Leone (1966-1967). In 1967, he became Associate Professor of Anthropology at San Francisco State University, from which he retired as a tenured Professor in 1986. He remained Professor Emeritus there until his death in 2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection contains original and secondary material related to Gamble's more than six decades of research on The Gambia and its peoples. This includes original notes, illustrations, maps, photographs, and correspondence produced during the anthropologist's extensive fieldwork among Mandinka, Wolof, Jola, and Fula communities in The Gambia. Copies of the anthropologist's publications on Gambian history, economics, languages, and cultures are included, along with many of the primary and secondary sources, including newspapers, photocopies of documents, books and periodicals, and government reports, from which he generated these studies. At the heart of Gamble's corpus of published work is his monumental 52-volume Gambian Studies series, a complete set of which is held in the collection. Gambian Studies is comprised of bibliographies of The Gambia; dictionaries and grammars of Wolof, Mandinka, and Fula languages; collections of folktales, stories, and proverbs; studies of historical sources; and general ethnographies of the country's people.

Gamble's research is topically wide-ranging and methodologically diverse, reflecting the influence of his mentors and his own eclectic expertise. Geographically, his work focuses on The Gambia, but extends to Senegal and Sierra Leone. Topics and issues covered include trade, agriculture, land tenure, law and legal systems, folklore, material culture, verbal and visual culture, language, life-cycle ceremonies, music, and the colonial encounter. Methods included mapping, census-taking, field observation, photography, sound recording, analysis of historical documents, and interviews. Gamble treated research projects iteratively, revisiting ideas and sources numerous times over the course of his career. Date ranges of accumulated research material can therefore be quite wide within a single subject area. Gamble's publications are, in many cases, present in both final and draft manuscript forms.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has been arranged in twelve series by subject matter and type of material.

list.item: Series 8: Jola, Lebu, Serer, and Serahuli research materials, 1920-2007
Series 9: Sierra Leone / Temne research materials, 1920-2007
Series 11: Gambian newspapers and periodicals, ca. 1960-2004

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Gamble's sound recordings and slide photographs, as well as his original collection indexes, are held in the UCLA Ethnomusicology Archive: David P. Gamble Collection (2011.08). Selected volumes of Gamble's Gambian Studies series are available for download through St. Mary's College of Maryland: http://www.smcm.edu/gambia/david_gamble.html.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of materials related to Gamble's early life, academic training, and teaching career. It includes his birth certificate, early family photographs, school and university certificates and diplomas, and references from his academic mentors. A variety of life history materials and documentation used in the writing of Gamble's 2002 autobiography, Gambian Research: the Anthropological Life of David P. Gamble, form a core part of this series. Representing his early academic training and his lifelong personal interest, Gamble's finished and unfinished research on the peoples of Northern Ireland is included here.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of materials related to Gamble's study of Wolof society, culture, language, and history. It includes notes from Gamble's fieldwork in Wolof areas, books and periodicals, annotated photocopies of primary and secondary sources, as well as maps, illustrations, and diagrams generated in the course of research. Gamble's research on the Wolof is extensive and includes the early history of Goree Island (Senegal), Wolof folktales and proverbs, and Wolof language and linguistic history. These materials are the foundation of Gamble's publications on the Wolof, including The Wolof of Senegambia, Together with Notes on the Lebu and the Serer (1957); and Gambian Studies volumes 10A, 10B, 22, 25, 26, 27, 37, and 50, which include his Wolof-English dictionaries and grammars. Series includes materials in English, French, and Wolof.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series follows original order, as listed in Gamble's collection index.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of materials related to Gamble's study of Mandinka society, culture, language, and history. It includes notes from Gamble's fieldwork in Mandinka areas, books and periodicals, annotated photocopies of primary and secondary sources, as well as maps, illustrations, and diagrams generated in the course of research. Gamble's dissertation, "An Analysis of the Economic Conditions and Underlying Factors in a Gambian Mandinka Community," (1958) and his earlier publications for the Research Department of the Colonial Office are based on extended stays in the villages of Kerewan and Keneba during the late 1940s and early 1950s. His research in Mandinka country was largely sociological, economic, and linguistic, focused on the collection and analysis of census data, the observation and documentation of land use and agricultural practices, and the mapping of each village's physical layout and kinship structures, as well as on the compilation of Mandinka vocabulary and grammar. Later work turned to the study of Mandinka folklore and ceremonies. Gamble's colonial-era publications and later writings on the Mandinka (Gambian Studies volumes 2-9, 20-21, 34, and 49) are included in the collection. Series includes materials in English, French, and Mandinka.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series follows original order, as listed in Gamble's collection index.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of materials related to Gamble's general research on The Gambia. It includes field notes and data related to Gamble's broad sociological surveys of the country's regions, as well as summaries and transcripts of primary sources consulted, including local "native" court records and district reports. This series is also comprised of notes on local and regional histories, as well as preparatory materials for Gamble's (1999) scholarly edition of Richard Jobson's The Discovery of River Gambra 1623. Professional correspondence regarding work in The Gambia and materials assembled for Gamble's anthropological exhibitions at San Francisco State University's Treganza Museum are also featured. Since there is some overlap between Gamble's general work on The Gambia and his ethnicity-based studies, some of the items in this series may be relevant to Mandinka, Wolof, and Fula research as well.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series follows original order, as listed in Gamble's collection index.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of materials related to Gamble's research into Gambian, Senegalese, and Malian music. Gamble pursued this study on behalf of a colleague, Susan Carpendale, who was interested in exploring the connections between African and African-American music. The series includes annotated photocopies of secondary sources, original notes on sound recordings and written sources, and related correspondence. The "griot" (praise singing) traditions of Sudanic West Africa are emphasized.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series follows original order, as listed in Gamble's collection index.

did.unittitle: Mark and Susan Pevar: notes on recordings and correspondence
Pekaan, epic song of the Subalbe (Senegal)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series is divided into two subseries: one comprised of original photographic prints and negatives generated during Gamble's work in Senegambia and Sierra Leone, and one consisting of photographs clipped from newspapers and periodicals. Gamble's research photography documents daily activities, material culture, dress and hair, musical instruments, land use and agricultural techniques, and housing and architecture among Wolof, Mandinka, Fula, and Jola peoples. Biographical photos and mounted photos used in exhibits at San Francisco State College are also included. The second subseries contains news clippings relevant to Gamble's research.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: The first subseries is arranged chronologically. The second subseries has not been processed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of material related to Gamble's study of Fula language and culture. It includes original field notes and bibliographies, Fula educational lesson books, and secondary articles related to the Fula language, as well as Fula grammars, dictionaries, and translations. Working drafts of Gamble's own Fula-English dictionary are included. There is some material related to Fula as an ethnic group. Series materials are in English, French, and Fula.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series has not been processed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Several folders of original DG field notes & bibliographies, Fula educational lesson books, some secondary articles related mostly to the Fula language, Fula grammar, Fula dictionaries, and translations. Some materials related to Fula as ethnic group. Materials in English, French, and Fula.

did.unittitle: Series 8: Lebu, Serer, Jola, and Serahuli research materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of original field notes, bibliographies, census data, and linguistic documentation, as well as secondary sources related to Gamble's study among Jola, Lebu, Serer, and Serahuli ethnic communities in The Gambia.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series has not been processed.

did.unittitle: Serahuli: general: offprints and extracts, notes on early sources (1 of 2)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of materials related to Gamble's research in and about Sierra Leone, and his work on a UNICEF project, "Develop Sierra Leone." It includes original field notes, questionnaires, and correspondence, as well as offprints and other secondary material related to Temne language and geography. The series also consists of photographic prints and negatives taken in Lunsar and other areas of Sierra Leone.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series has not been processed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of bound copies of Gamble's monumental 52-volume self-published book series, Gambian Studies. It includes bibliographies of The Gambia; dictionaries and grammars of Wolof, Mandinka, and Fula languages; collections of folktales, stories, and proverbs; studies of historical sources; and general ethnographies of the country's people.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged chronologically, by volume number.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of newspapers and periodicals published in The Gambia between 1960 and 2004. Publications include Daily Observer, Weekend Observer, Gambian News Bulletin, and West Africa, among others.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series has not been processed.

did.unittitle: Gambian News Bulletin and West Africa

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series is divided into two subseries: the first is comprised of theses collected by Gamble in the course of his research and the second consists of miscellaneous books not originally associated with other series.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series has not been processed.
